item.description:
Thought it might be fun to do something a little different this week.  Since nothing on the regular movie release list for this week seemed interesting to me, I decided to check out other venues to see what is happening.   Look what I found is coming out at the Brattle Theater in Harvard Square.  I have heard this film is verrry creepy. 

This time I know the start time of the film.   Showtime is 7:30.  Since there is no convenient gathering place before the film,  I won't arrive till around 7.   We will probably be allowed up into the theater around 7:15.  

Please be warned.  This is a smaller theater in the heart of Harvard Square and I strongly advise you to buy your tickets ahead of time.   They are already on sale.  To get one for yourself, please go to:  Buy Tickets

Unlike conventional theaters, they are very good about starting things on time here and with only a couple of previews.   So arriving late will likely mean you will miss out on part of the movie.

If you miss the group ahead of time, come find us after.  We gather on the sidewalk outside of the theater to discuss the film a bit, and to get a head count of all those who would like to go out after for drinks and munchies. 

Managing the after event is much easier if everyone brings cash, so please plan ahead if you want to go out with the group after and bring cash.

 

Movie Details:

Kill List

Area Premiere March 2–8! Co-presented with Independent Film Festival Boston (2011) dir Ben Wheatley w/Neil Maskell, Michael Smiley, MyAnne Buring, Harry Simpson, Emma Fryer [95 min]

The newest from acclaimed British director Ben Wheatley (Down Terrace), KILL LIST is an intricately constructed film that almost begs to be seen more than once. A brilliant blend of family drama, crime thriller and terrifying psychological horror, KILL LIST tells the story of an ex-soldier turned contract killer who is plunged into the heart of human darkness. Eight months after a disastrous job in Kiev, Jay (Maskell) is pressured by his partner Gal (Smiley) into taking a new assignment. Neither man, however, no matter how hardened they may be, has any idea just how dark and twisted this new job is.

The film wisely avoids extraneous exposition, leaving the audience asking questions at the same time (and sometimes with the same level of desperation) as Jay and Gal. Wheatley’s direction treats family confrontation and armed showdowns with a naturalistic shooting style, drawing us into Jay’s paranoid worldview before pulling the rug out from under us with a stunningly shocking ending. We can practically guarantee that this is one of those films that you will be talking about for weeks after seeing it.

 “KILL LIST is a definite widescreen cinematic experience loaded with delicious details…  It’s also the kind of movie designed to mess up your mind, like some unseen Nicolas Roeg or Ken Russell picture.” – Andrew O’Hehir, Salon.com

“A shocking, emotionally resonant and horrific ride. KILL LIST will leave your bones rattling.” –Drew Taylor, Indiewire

“It’s the scariest hit man movie I’ve ever seen.” –Todd Gilchrist, BoxOffice Magazine
item.how_to_find_us: I will be wearing a meetup pin. I will be waiting outside by the ticket booth until they let us in the lobby. The group will wait in the lobby till they let us upstairs, probably around 7:15.
item.name: The Kill List (7:30 Show)
